The following is the substance of news
from Constantinople TO the 10th of April, re-
ceived At Trieste on the 9Th of Nav


Lord Cochraen, who arrived III Greece
with brig, a large schooner, and about
the French Philhellenes, declared to the
Assembl, at Egna, that he was come to as
sst the Greeks in recovering their liberty,
and that he desired to be appointed High
Admiral of their feet. The Hytlriots did
not at first seem inclined to obey a foreigner,
but Lord Cothrane having declared that he
could not serve except on this condition, and
that otherwise he should withdraw they
consented, and his Lordship having been
unanimously appointed High Admiral, had
squadron equipped composed of his two
vessels, the American frigate Hellas, the
Perseverance, (steamboat) and four chosen
Hydriot ships, in all eight sail, with which
he is gone on secret expedition. 1t is
thought that the Admiral will go to Negro.
pont and Seitonni. or towards the Mediter.
ranean. 1t is sad that the Porte is much
alarmed at the arrival of Lsrd Cochrane
and that it uses cyery exertion that its fee
may put TO sea as soon as possible under tn,
com mand Of certain Soieiman of Alexan
d,a, who is resolved to measure his strength
with the English Admiral. Eight men Of
war; two frigates, four corvetts, and brigs
have already sailed from the Dardandelles
They will be followed by thrty-sx othe
men n-of-war and many transports"

Il ence, nc hurled a lamp which stood near
AZ his more fortunate adversary the olow
vas not doomed to descend ON him. Ihe
boy, Julio, had entered u1observed. . on HIM
the vengeful missile fell; the dark haired
page received the blow.


''Noblc boy. my life has been preserved
by thee'" exclaimed Stemford, and he re-
ceived the scuseless form OF the page IN his
arms.


"He. does but faint" he continued, in a
tone of alarm: "Airl air!-let him have arr
it is only a swoon!"


With speed the still lifrless form OF Julio
was borne to an open window. otelnford
tore from his head a black hilet, winch the
boy said concealed wound, scar there was
none; but IN his snowy temple there APP
peared deep cash, from which no blood
issued.


The handkerchief was now united, and
hi, vest opened--and, to the astonishment OF
all present, the white bosom OF a female was
exposed TO view, while around her neck de-
pended miniature.


Oh that sight struck deeply on the heart
of Henry: he knew the portrait--he knew
she dead girls form.


"Roslinei" I" he exclaimed, in bitter an
guish-."your vow has not been broken-you
are indeed avenged"


He prayed fervently for his death-i'
came not--aud he lived many, many years
out If broken heart testified repentance
Stcinford's was sincere.

The ignorance of the proper mode o.
cooking vegetables, and especially OF dress
ing salads, which exists among the mid
ding class, retards improvements IN garden
:ng. Loudtn says IA Frcnch la3orer, cut
Of few leaves of Landclion and wild sorrei,
which may be gathered BY tie hcdge-sides
any where, and almost at any time, will
produce merely by the aid of the common
condiments, what the wives of the greater
part of respectable British tradesuicn have
40 idea Of" There can be no great demand
for thing of which the use is not thorough
iy understood; and therefore AN improve-
rnent in the knowledge and practice of
cooking must take place among a certain
class, before much can be expected in the
quantity, kind, or quality of the gardening
articles which they commonly consume.

The Farmers Magazine. British pu6li-
cation contains the following: Having
long entertained an idea that the formation


of apples upon potatoes was detrimental to
the crop, by drawing away large and val.


uable part Of the nourishment from the
roots, l this year made an experiment which
think goes great way to solve the ques-
tion. Having planted some of different
kinds, had the flowers carefully picked
from several Of the drills as soon as they ap-
peared, leaving between every drill so pick
ed, drill with the flowers untouched. In
some cases ! allowed the flowers to expand
and even to make some progress towards
setting, in others, suffered the apples to
.orm. end pulled them off when they were

discord. is overcome; what remains 10 per
form is now rendered easy. The people on
ryery side rush to arms--the fate OF the ~
cropolis is no longer doubtful-thc besiegers
in their turn are besieged--the transport OF
provisions is intercepted--the passes are
guarded, and retreat is become impossio'c'
The liberty of the classic soil OF Athens IS
cnsured-once more will its arts hourish
there.


"Oh Greeks having attained this object,
Law not aside YOUR arms SO long as the tero-
cious Mussulman treads the sacred land OF
YOUR fathers. Let a noble emulation tor
glory, animate your young scaInen and tne
heroes of the Continent--lett them hasten IN

session of all your rights are suthcicht 70 en-
able YOU to stop the passage OF tue flelies-
pont, and carry the war into the states OF the
enemy, the naughty Sultan-the sansulnaiy
DESTROYER of your countrymen-willb become
the victim of his own subjects. he Ma
homedan power will destroy itself! ne
banner Of the Cross will again ioat on the
walls of St. Sopha-Greece will again nave
laws--her cities will rise once more from
their ruins-and her future glory VIII equal
that of the past But think not, oh Greek s.
that your country will be free, unless each
of Won hastens to her assistance and defence.

among the supplements OF agriculture III all
ages. Noah cultivated the vine and made

kind, ,--and he gives fsure Of une or an an
cent medal dug up at syracuse, which re
sembles pickaxr. The letter \ (alpha)

| plough; in the most ancient form OF the


Greek A, one branch ,the beanil is twice
| as long as the o'her (the sMrc.l Another
ancient plough ti6urea by NJ. Loudon Is IN
the form of Il sharp toed boot. the holder "a
femalr) has one hand on tho Top at she bopt,


aud beam is inserted a litt!r above the i'll
step. The Instrument nos Used tor plough
| inc by the nations cf the east, is similar 20
those of the ancicnts Mr.. Loudon remarks
I that the state Of agriculture and other arts,


and Of machinery, IN the ea,tern countries.

long wedge sh sped thing, and the beam AVID

some Of them resemble the brush Soythe o'


the American farmer, the blade bting used


for il share. and the handle for BEAM


thy are guided by piece Ot wood attached


to the beam near the share.-Ihe Eindot
p,ourhs merely scratch the earth, and Il
accomplish the work Of pu,verlzaton, the
ploughmsu repeats the operation from five


TO fifteen times. The Chinese pnughs ar,


simple, and some of them are drawn by wo


men.


The ancicot Greek plough, described BY
lIesiod, consisted Of three parts-a los,
} block sh4rpened at the point; draught


pole attached obliquely to the upper part o


the block, and extending TO the yoke; ant


plough tail to direct the implement. fastened
in like manner and extending back, 4


plough of similar construction is now use
III Sicily, l he plough vt the modern Treek
& has a crooked share shaped ike the claw q

, soping handle, which is large and strong
The most ancient plough used by the r.


mans, was Of the simplest form. III III


days OF Virgil, this implement had becom


more complicated aud efficient They ha

with and without couIters: with and withou


,u,a p,it arI

of the ploughs of most ancient and som

A correspondent of the American Farm
er gives the following as new process for
picking cucumbers, by substituting whsAey
when vinegar is scarce:


gathered the cucumbers from the vines,
and without any other preparation than
washing them clean, dropped them into a
stand containing mixture of whiskey and
water, oae part Of the former to three Of the
latter. secured them against gnats, fies,
and external air, by tying flannel close
over the top, and laying over this a board
and stone, and neither moved nor examined
them until Christmas, when l found them
not merely equal, but decidedly superior to
any pickle had ever tasted They were
hard and of fine navor, and what has been
particularly admired in them. thcy retained
the original color of the cucu nber, not ex-
hibiting the green poisonous appearance OF
pickles that had been salted and scalded in
copper. My whiskey and water (no salt
having seen used or heat employed,) is now
excellent vinegar for the table

were gathered as soon as they appeared. INC

apples were allowed to come to maturity;

it was still less though greatly better than

Loudon's Gardeners Magazine says I'VE
are sorry to observe that practice of pinch
ing off potatoc blossoms IS not generally A.
dopted, as the produce would thereby DC
materially increased. A correspondent mas
found Fl ON experience that the crop IS NOT
onlv increased, but much better in quaiity


and wishes Us to direct the attention OF ouI


readers to the practice. which we hereby 90,
fully convinced of its Importance.

We congratulate our sporting friends on a
novel kind Of racing which has Just been es-
t.hlishrd IN the vicinity Of Liverpool. All
TIC town knows, that number of choice
sPlrlts assemble. during the Sumner even
ings. IN the grccu contiguous to st. Georges
hotel. E,crton, for the purpose Of enjoying
the 4 dtlirltFu eXcrcIsr OF bowling Among
the group ma" Ne seen the pOrtly lawyer,
the bulky phvician, and the wealthy mcr-
chant, who tier" invigorate themselves after
The tells OF the dav. bv impe!lins the BOWL
across the smooth green Sward. A few even
ings ago the party met as usual; out the
green, unfortunately, was out OF order, and
the bowlrrs coud not follow their usual pas
ting. What was tn be done! Nariods plans
were proposed. md succcssively rejected
At length fott-racc between two OF the
company was ptopostd Il. A son Of Esculap-
ins challenged a foreign gentleman to run
him a race along the grav-lled walk. The
chal'ange was, that the former wsuld run
fifty yards, witt the heaviest man in the
company on his back, in shorter time than
the latter would run one hundred yards un-
incumbercd. The challenge was accepted,
and the wager was glasses round. But dit
! ticulty now arose to dett rhine which OF the
gentlemen present possessed the greatest
gravity. We have already said that there
was a portly LAWYER in the company. All
ewes were instantly fixed on him; and he
was requested, with one consent. to act the
Jockey on the occasion. Our friend loves
good joke almost as well as he loves good
dinner; and he, without hesitation, accept
ed the situation The man of physic stood to
receive his learned rider, who mounted, as
quickly as he could, the broad back of the
biped. The foreigner then took his stand
beside his competitor. The signal for start
ing was now gwen, and off set the parties,
at full speed, down the gravelled walk
I Esculapius, Notwithstanding he carried the
lawyer, like Coke uhon LHt(eton, soon out


sped his burdrness competitor; and scam


pered away w,th his load of law with AS
much ease, as if he had a mere boy upon his
shoulders His rival and the rest of the


company struggled after him in vain. But
how shall we describe the catastrophe


which befel him when he was within few


wards of the winning post! The course IS
nor one of the most even in the werld, and
it is thickly strewed with sharp stones


We'll, when Ksoulapius was in the height


of his career, and the goal ia'l in view, his


foot struck against onethlng. He stumbled


he tottered, and down came law and physic


with concussitm which shock to its very
r foundation the tower of Everton church,
Alas, Alas!


CT fell down and broke his crown,


And p. came turnbling after"


e The blood flowed, in copi?ns streams, frou


the nostris of Esculapius; but he sprang


like Antanus, from the earth; with Her


culean strength he threw the lawyer behin'
;, his back, and pressing on with quickcne,
). speed, reached the goal before his competi


tor had completed two-thiIds of his task
9 he was declared t.. victor amidst the plau
). dts OF the spectators, who congratulate
him on the prodigious strength which h


had displayed in winning the race with 9Th
6 Statutes at large" upon his shoulders.

a fatal accident occurred at wolf hunt
near Willanstown, Mass. According to
arrangement large number Of men assem-
bled from the neighbourng towns, and hav-
ing formed a circle around the mountain
where two wolves had been observed, drew
nearer and nearer towards the top. A volt
was killed on his way up. And on the sum-
nit fox was started and fired Al BY several
persons at the same moment. Unfortunate"
~ one of the balls struck young NAH Of the
party i'll the head and caused his Geath in
few minutes. The hunters, who are stat
edby some at 700, and by others at l,loO.
formed PROCESSION, and took the body to its
friends.

The eleventh annual report OF the Deaf
and Dumb Asylum at Hartford has been
published. This institution began only with
seven pupils, but the whole number who
have been educated at it is two hundred and
twenty seven, and of these about one half
have left the asylum. These, with a few
exceptions, have been raised from a most
complete state of ignorance and blankness Of
intellect to degree Of intelligence and re.
spectability, qualified to perform all the
duties ct citizens, and to procure livelihood
by their own industry. Five of those whose
education has been completed, have been
employed as assistant teachers, either in the
Hartford asylum or in similar institutions.-
Of the whole number admitted into the in
stitution, thrty-eight are from Connecticut,
one from Havana. and the rest from differ
ent States of the Union. One hundred and
thirty pupils are now in the institution, of
which there are hftyhve supported by
the State of Massachusetts. twenty-five by
Vermont, twelve BY New Hampshire, and
by Maine.

To hreSerpe Currants.-Gather currants
when green, separate them from stems, and
put them in junk bottles; cork the but'les
closely. and place them in cool part Of the
cellar Currsnts may be kept fresh and
green in this manner twelve months or more,
and will make excellent pies in the winter
and spring; so say some of our friends who
have tried the experiment several times.

any other 7vooien cloth.


Dissolve piece of pearl ash, of the size
of pea, in half tea cup of warm water. or
piece twice the size, in full tea cup
Pour snme of the solution Or a grease spot,
and continue to rub il with clean brush or
woolen cloth, until it is nearly dry, and your
carpet or garment will be clean as ever.

Joseph Lancaster, the celebrated founder
nf the I.ancasteran system of instruction,
arrived at New Haven few days since
from the Island of St. Croix. He has been
travelling in different parts of South Amer.
ica for several years, and has attempted to
introduce his schools in Caracas ard other
places in Colombia His plans, we under
stand, have not been successful and he has
left that country dissatisfied. Mr. Lancas-
ter WAS to deliver public lecture in the
Centre Church in NewHaven yesterday
~ \. HdU.

Termination Of Slavery in the State Of
Nt'79- York.-The first act of the legislature
Of this state, which led to the final olsen
thrapent of all slaves within the jurisdiction
of New-York, and passed in 1899, and de-
clared all children Of slave mothers, born on
aud after the 4th day Of July of the same
year were born free, but should remain the
servants Of the master or mistress OF the
mother,--the male children until they
reached the aye of 20, and the females %
the age of IS. provided the master or mis-,
tress caused the children to be taught to read
the Holy Scriptures previous to their Dc-
coming q years of age. On the 3ist OF
March. 1917, the Legislature repealed tha'
section of law which embraced the above
provisions. and passed another law, winch
provided. chat all children Of ol"~S n,other'
born after the passage of the law then e.
nacted, should serve their master or mistress
until they were twenty one years OF age
provided they were taught to read, or re-
ceivcd three quarters schooling previous 10
their becoming eighteen years Of age. hno.
ther section of the same law declared. tha'
on and after the FOURTH DAY or Ju-
I.Y. l827, all siares in this state, Born "efofS
the fourlA day IF July 1899, shall be u"e'n-

To dye Cotton a Buff Color.-Let the
cleanse it, then wiring it, run it through "a
dilute solution of iron in the vegetable acid,
which painters call sron liquor; wiring and
run it through lime water, to raise it: wiring
it again, and run it through solution OF
starch and water; then wiring it once more,
and dry, wind, wrap, and weave it for use

To treserve MNk.-A spoonful Of horse
radsh put into pan of milk, ii is said, will
preserve it sweet for several DAYS.


Mix Dief-An English writer, in q trea
ties on milk, states in his recommendation
of milk as an article of diet, that the town
of Kendall in England, where more milk is
used in proportion to the number of lnhabit-
ants, than in any othertown in England, fur
nishes more Instances of longevity and few
er deaths among children, than any ether
town.

To hreserve Houses from Fermin.-Bugs
in particular, may readily be destroyed ny
dissolving half drachm of corrosive subli-
mate in quarter of an ounce of spirits Of
salts. mixing it with one quart of spirits Of
turpentine. Shake these well together, dip
brush in it. and wash those places where
the bug, are supposed TO resort

Ratfie8ndkes.-Two men from Bradford
county, were at our shores yesterday. with
a Box, containing seventy.fv hpe Rattle.
snakes. These snakes were caught at sew.
eral dens in May last, soon after the warmth
of the sun induced them to leave their hid.
ing places, but before they had acquired
their usual and ordinary activity. In taking
them, wooden tongs we're used of sufficient
length to seize them without exposing the
captors to much danger. The owners Of
these poisonous reptiles. have descended
thus far with them in Canoe, and propose
going to Philadelphia by the Union Canal
and it will probably be the first boat, as we'll
as the first cargo cfthe kind which will pass
through the canal. They ought to 20 toN
free. The ultimate destination ofthese reo.
tiles is Europe, where they will unquestion-
ably attract much attention, as indeed thew
are objects Of great curiosity in many parts
of our own country Uikes6arre ha.

full articles.headline:
roNEEGN xsSTEGEIGLNCE.

THE GREEKS.
full articles.article:
The following is the substance of news
from Constantinople TO the 10th of April, re-
ceived At Trieste on the 9Th of Nav


Lord Cochraen, who arrived III Greece
with brig, a large schooner, and about
the French Philhellenes, declared to the
Assembl, at Egna, that he was come to as
sst the Greeks in recovering their liberty,
and that he desired to be appointed High
Admiral of their feet. The Hytlriots did
not at first seem inclined to obey a foreigner,
but Lord Cothrane having declared that he
could not serve except on this condition, and
that otherwise he should withdraw they
consented, and his Lordship having been
unanimously appointed High Admiral, had
squadron equipped composed of his two
vessels, the American frigate Hellas, the
Perseverance, (steamboat) and four chosen
Hydriot ships, in all eight sail, with which
he is gone on secret expedition. 1t is
thought that the Admiral will go to Negro.
pont and Seitonni. or towards the Mediter.
ranean. 1t is sad that the Porte is much
alarmed at the arrival of Lsrd Cochrane
and that it uses cyery exertion that its fee
may put TO sea as soon as possible under tn,
com mand Of certain Soieiman of Alexan
d,a, who is resolved to measure his strength
with the English Admiral. Eight men Of
war; two frigates, four corvetts, and brigs
have already sailed from the Dardandelles
They will be followed by thrty-sx othe
men n-of-war and many transports"


LORD COCHRANE'S PROCLAMA-


TlON.


"G-ceks-Your most dangerous enemy

Il ence, nc hurled a lamp which stood near
AZ his more fortunate adversary the olow
vas not doomed to descend ON him. Ihe
boy, Julio, had entered u1observed. . on HIM
the vengeful missile fell; the dark haired
page received the blow.


''Noblc boy. my life has been preserved
by thee'" exclaimed Stemford, and he re-
ceived the scuseless form OF the page IN his
arms.


"He. does but faint" he continued, in a
tone of alarm: "Airl air!-let him have arr
it is only a swoon!"


With speed the still lifrless form OF Julio
was borne to an open window. otelnford
tore from his head a black hilet, winch the
boy said concealed wound, scar there was
none; but IN his snowy temple there APP
peared deep cash, from which no blood
issued.


The handkerchief was now united, and
hi, vest opened--and, to the astonishment OF
all present, the white bosom OF a female was
exposed TO view, while around her neck de-
pended miniature.


Oh that sight struck deeply on the heart
of Henry: he knew the portrait--he knew
she dead girls form.


"Roslinei" I" he exclaimed, in bitter an
guish-."your vow has not been broken-you
are indeed avenged"


He prayed fervently for his death-i'
came not--aud he lived many, many years
out If broken heart testified repentance
Stcinford's was sincere.

full articles.article:
The ignorance of the proper mode o.
cooking vegetables, and especially OF dress
ing salads, which exists among the mid
ding class, retards improvements IN garden
:ng. Loudtn says IA Frcnch la3orer, cut
Of few leaves of Landclion and wild sorrei,
which may be gathered BY tie hcdge-sides
any where, and almost at any time, will
produce merely by the aid of the common
condiments, what the wives of the greater
part of respectable British tradesuicn have
40 idea Of" There can be no great demand
for thing of which the use is not thorough
iy understood; and therefore AN improve-
rnent in the knowledge and practice of
cooking must take place among a certain
class, before much can be expected in the
quantity, kind, or quality of the gardening
articles which they commonly consume.

full articles.headline: Picking off Potatoe Blossoms.
full articles.article:
The Farmers Magazine. British pu6li-
cation contains the following: Having
long entertained an idea that the formation


of apples upon potatoes was detrimental to
the crop, by drawing away large and val.


uable part Of the nourishment from the
roots, l this year made an experiment which
think goes great way to solve the ques-
tion. Having planted some of different
kinds, had the flowers carefully picked
from several Of the drills as soon as they ap-
peared, leaving between every drill so pick
ed, drill with the flowers untouched. In
some cases ! allowed the flowers to expand
and even to make some progress towards
setting, in others, suffered the apples to
.orm. end pulled them off when they were
h>,fGrorn In the drills whers the fiowers

discord. is overcome; what remains 10 per
form is now rendered easy. The people on
ryery side rush to arms--the fate OF the ~
cropolis is no longer doubtful-thc besiegers
in their turn are besieged--the transport OF
provisions is intercepted--the passes are
guarded, and retreat is become impossio'c'
The liberty of the classic soil OF Athens IS
cnsured-once more will its arts hourish
there.


"Oh Greeks having attained this object,
Law not aside YOUR arms SO long as the tero-
cious Mussulman treads the sacred land OF
YOUR fathers. Let a noble emulation tor
glory, animate your young scaInen and tne
heroes of the Continent--lett them hasten IN
a mass to take their stations in the national
fleet. Then, if independence and the pos
session of all your rights are suthcicht 70 en-
able YOU to stop the passage OF tue flelies-
pont, and carry the war into the states OF the
enemy, the naughty Sultan-the sansulnaiy
DESTROYER of your countrymen-willb become
the victim of his own subjects. he Ma
homedan power will destroy itself! ne
banner Of the Cross will again ioat on the
walls of St. Sopha-Greece will again nave
laws--her cities will rise once more from
their ruins-and her future glory VIII equal
that of the past But think not, oh Greek s.
that your country will be free, unless each
of Won hastens to her assistance and defence.


t.From on boaid the Greek vessel Heiias,
The first Admiral Commander OF the mara
time forces Of Greeks.

full articles.headline: THE PLOUGH.
full articles.article:
MS instrument mas nolu Inc nTSt pIdIe
among the supplements OF agriculture III all
ages. Noah cultivated the vine and made
vine Immediately after the flood, but II is
supposed that grain was first cultivated on
the banks ofthe Nile, in Egypt. The inSen-
tion OF the plough must have been nearly CO.
eval with the raising of grain. "Tht plough"
says Jahn, in his Biblical Archaeology, was
nothing mare than stuIt limb of a tree,
from which projected another shortened
and pointed limb. The further end OF the
longer branch was fastened to the yoke, and
u handle was added BY which the plough
might be guided" Mr.. Loudon says the
plough originally used, was of the PICK
kind, ,--and he gives fsure Of une or an an
cent medal dug up at syracuse, which re
sembles pickaxr. The letter \ (alpha)
| is supposed to have It's shape from the
| plough; in the most ancient form OF the


Greek A, one branch ,the beanil is twice
| as long as the o'her (the sMrc.l Another
ancient plough ti6urea by NJ. Loudon Is IN
the form of Il sharp toed boot. the holder "a
femalr) has one hand on tho Top at she bopt,


aud beam is inserted a litt!r above the i'll
step. The Instrument nos Used tor plough
| inc by the nations cf the east, is similar 20
those of the ancicnts Mr.. Loudon remarks
I that the state Of agriculture and other arts,


and Of machinery, IN the ea,tern countries.
/ was not materially different in the time Of
I Moses $500 years ago, from what Il is IN
/ the same countries at the present day. In
\ Persia the lower part o. the plough is a


long wedge sh sped thing, and the beam AVID
! handle are inserted in thctop OF thls block;
4 in some districts the diver stands Oh the
wedge or sharrs. In Hiuiostan the ploughs


are of the stick shape and are but little bet


ter than pointed sticks. l he figures OF
some Of them resemble the brush Soythe o'


the American farmer, the blade bting used


for il share. and the handle for BEAM


thy are guided by piece Ot wood attached


to the beam near the share.-Ihe Eindot
p,ourhs merely scratch the earth, and Il
accomplish the work Of pu,verlzaton, the
ploughmsu repeats the operation from five


TO fifteen times. The Chinese pnughs ar,


simple, and some of them are drawn by wo


men.


The ancicot Greek plough, described BY
lIesiod, consisted Of three parts-a los,
} block sh4rpened at the point; draught


pole attached obliquely to the upper part o


the block, and extending TO the yoke; ant


plough tail to direct the implement. fastened
in like manner and extending back, 4


plough of similar construction is now use
III Sicily, l he plough vt the modern Treek
& has a crooked share shaped ike the claw q
+ an anchor; il is only a continuation Of TIL
, soping handle, which is large and strong
The most ancient plough used by the r.


mans, was Of the simplest form. III III


days OF Virgil, this implement had becom


more complicated aud efficient They ha
G ploughs with and without mouldboards
with and without couIters: with and withou


,u,a p,it arI
: shares. The beam was fastened 10 the yoke
n like our cart pole. The Romans did nc
n plough their lands in beds or ridges. as W
S do; but the cattle always rctnrn in the sam
: furrow. The plough commonly used ha
: no mould-board, and this may tie rcmarke
of the ploughs of most ancient and som
+ modern nations

full articles.headline: p1CKIING CuCuMRERS.
full articles.article:
A correspondent of the American Farm
er gives the following as new process for
picking cucumbers, by substituting whsAey
when vinegar is scarce:


gathered the cucumbers from the vines,
and without any other preparation than
washing them clean, dropped them into a
stand containing mixture of whiskey and
water, oae part Of the former to three Of the
latter. secured them against gnats, fies,
and external air, by tying flannel close
over the top, and laying over this a board
and stone, and neither moved nor examined
them until Christmas, when l found them
not merely equal, but decidedly superior to
any pickle had ever tasted They were
hard and of fine navor, and what has been
particularly admired in them. thcy retained
the original color of the cucu nber, not ex-
hibiting the green poisonous appearance OF
pickles that had been salted and scalded in
copper. My whiskey and water (no salt
having seen used or heat employed,) is now
excellent vinegar for the table

were gathered as soon as they appeared. INC
crop was double to what it was where the
apples were allowed to come to maturity;
where the flowers we're allowed to waste
themselves the crop was less abundant, and
where the apples had made some progress
it was still less though greatly better than
where they had been left untouched III
short, from the time of the flowers appear
ing, and as long as the leaves continued green
and the stems growing, there appeared an
advantage from gathering both tue ho"ers
and apples, gradually, diminishing however
as they approach the ultimate period OF
their growth. | remarked also that the
stems of the potatoes in the drills where
the flowers had been picked of, continued
green and vigorous much longer than where
they were suffered to grow, and also where
the apples were gathered at an early PERI
cd. l, at the same time, made trlals as 10
the effects of cutting the haulM at dhtrent
stages OF its growth. all Of which found ru-
| inous, the deficiency of the crop beng IN eA-
act proportion with the eariness OF the cut


ting, with this addition, that the POTATOES
were i'll rpened aud of very bad quality:


Loudon's Gardeners Magazine says I'VE
are sorry to observe that practice of pinch
ing off potatoc blossoms IS not generally A.
dopted, as the produce would thereby DC
materially increased. A correspondent mas
found Fl ON experience that the crop IS NOT
onlv increased, but much better in quaiity


and wishes Us to direct the attention OF ouI


readers to the practice. which we hereby 90,
fully convinced of its Importance.

full articles.headline: LIVERPOOL. RACES.
full articles.article:
We congratulate our sporting friends on a
novel kind Of racing which has Just been es-
t.hlishrd IN the vicinity Of Liverpool. All
TIC town knows, that number of choice
sPlrlts assemble. during the Sumner even
ings. IN the grccu contiguous to st. Georges
hotel. E,crton, for the purpose Of enjoying
the 4 dtlirltFu eXcrcIsr OF bowling Among
the group ma" Ne seen the pOrtly lawyer,
the bulky phvician, and the wealthy mcr-
chant, who tier" invigorate themselves after
The tells OF the dav. bv impe!lins the BOWL
across the smooth green Sward. A few even
ings ago the party met as usual; out the
green, unfortunately, was out OF order, and
the bowlrrs coud not follow their usual pas
ting. What was tn be done! Nariods plans
were proposed. md succcssively rejected
At length fott-racc between two OF the
company was ptopostd Il. A son Of Esculap-
ins challenged a foreign gentleman to run
him a race along the grav-lled walk. The
chal'ange was, that the former wsuld run
fifty yards, witt the heaviest man in the
company on his back, in shorter time than
the latter would run one hundred yards un-
incumbercd. The challenge was accepted,
and the wager was glasses round. But dit
! ticulty now arose to dett rhine which OF the
gentlemen present possessed the greatest
gravity. We have already said that there
was a portly LAWYER in the company. All
ewes were instantly fixed on him; and he
was requested, with one consent. to act the
Jockey on the occasion. Our friend loves
good joke almost as well as he loves good
dinner; and he, without hesitation, accept
ed the situation The man of physic stood to
receive his learned rider, who mounted, as
quickly as he could, the broad back of the
biped. The foreigner then took his stand
beside his competitor. The signal for start
ing was now gwen, and off set the parties,
at full speed, down the gravelled walk
I Esculapius, Notwithstanding he carried the
lawyer, like Coke uhon LHt(eton, soon out


sped his burdrness competitor; and scam


pered away w,th his load of law with AS
much ease, as if he had a mere boy upon his
shoulders His rival and the rest of the


company struggled after him in vain. But
how shall we describe the catastrophe


which befel him when he was within few


wards of the winning post! The course IS
nor one of the most even in the werld, and
it is thickly strewed with sharp stones


We'll, when Ksoulapius was in the height


of his career, and the goal ia'l in view, his


foot struck against onethlng. He stumbled


he tottered, and down came law and physic


with concussitm which shock to its very
r foundation the tower of Everton church,
Alas, Alas!


CT fell down and broke his crown,


And p. came turnbling after"


e The blood flowed, in copi?ns streams, frou


the nostris of Esculapius; but he sprang


like Antanus, from the earth; with Her


culean strength he threw the lawyer behin'
;, his back, and pressing on with quickcne,
). speed, reached the goal before his competi


tor had completed two-thiIds of his task
9 he was declared t.. victor amidst the plau
). dts OF the spectators, who congratulate
him on the prodigious strength which h


had displayed in winning the race with 9Th
6 Statutes at large" upon his shoulders.
r --

a fatal accident occurred at wolf hunt
near Willanstown, Mass. According to
arrangement large number Of men assem-
bled from the neighbourng towns, and hav-
ing formed a circle around the mountain
where two wolves had been observed, drew
nearer and nearer towards the top. A volt
was killed on his way up. And on the sum-
nit fox was started and fired Al BY several
persons at the same moment. Unfortunate"
~ one of the balls struck young NAH Of the
party i'll the head and caused his Geath in
few minutes. The hunters, who are stat
edby some at 700, and by others at l,loO.
formed PROCESSION, and took the body to its
friends.

The eleventh annual report OF the Deaf
and Dumb Asylum at Hartford has been
published. This institution began only with
seven pupils, but the whole number who
have been educated at it is two hundred and
twenty seven, and of these about one half
have left the asylum. These, with a few
exceptions, have been raised from a most
complete state of ignorance and blankness Of
intellect to degree Of intelligence and re.
spectability, qualified to perform all the
duties ct citizens, and to procure livelihood
by their own industry. Five of those whose
education has been completed, have been
employed as assistant teachers, either in the
Hartford asylum or in similar institutions.-
Of the whole number admitted into the in
stitution, thrty-eight are from Connecticut,
one from Havana. and the rest from differ
ent States of the Union. One hundred and
thirty pupils are now in the institution, of
which there are hftyhve supported by
the State of Massachusetts. twenty-five by
Vermont, twelve BY New Hampshire, and
by Maine.

To hreSerpe Currants.-Gather currants
when green, separate them from stems, and
put them in junk bottles; cork the but'les
closely. and place them in cool part Of the
cellar Currsnts may be kept fresh and
green in this manner twelve months or more,
and will make excellent pies in the winter
and spring; so say some of our friends who
have tried the experiment several times.

Joseph Lancaster, the celebrated founder
nf the I.ancasteran system of instruction,
arrived at New Haven few days since
from the Island of St. Croix. He has been
travelling in different parts of South Amer.
ica for several years, and has attempted to
introduce his schools in Caracas ard other
places in Colombia His plans, we under
stand, have not been successful and he has
left that country dissatisfied. Mr. Lancas-
ter WAS to deliver public lecture in the
Centre Church in NewHaven yesterday
~ \. HdU.

year were born free, but should remain the
servants Of the master or mistress OF the

reached the aye of 20, and the females %
the age of IS. provided the master or mis-,
tress caused the children to be taught to read
the Holy Scriptures previous to their Dc-

March. 1917, the Legislature repealed tha'

born after the passage of the law then e.
nacted, should serve their master or mistress
until they were twenty one years OF age
provided they were taught to read, or re-
ceivcd three quarters schooling previous 10
their becoming eighteen years Of age. hno.

on and after the FOURTH DAY or Ju-

To dye Cotton a Buff Color.-Let the
cleanse it, then wiring it, run it through "a
dilute solution of iron in the vegetable acid,
which painters call sron liquor; wiring and
run it through lime water, to raise it: wiring
it again, and run it through solution OF
starch and water; then wiring it once more,
and dry, wind, wrap, and weave it for use

To treserve MNk.-A spoonful Of horse
radsh put into pan of milk, ii is said, will
preserve it sweet for several DAYS.


Mix Dief-An English writer, in q trea
ties on milk, states in his recommendation
of milk as an article of diet, that the town
of Kendall in England, where more milk is
used in proportion to the number of lnhabit-
ants, than in any othertown in England, fur
nishes more Instances of longevity and few
er deaths among children, than any ether
town.

To hreserve Houses from Fermin.-Bugs
in particular, may readily be destroyed ny
dissolving half drachm of corrosive subli-
mate in quarter of an ounce of spirits Of
salts. mixing it with one quart of spirits Of
turpentine. Shake these well together, dip
brush in it. and wash those places where
the bug, are supposed TO resort

Ratfie8ndkes.-Two men from Bradford
county, were at our shores yesterday. with
a Box, containing seventy.fv hpe Rattle.
snakes. These snakes were caught at sew.
eral dens in May last, soon after the warmth
of the sun induced them to leave their hid.
ing places, but before they had acquired
their usual and ordinary activity. In taking
them, wooden tongs we're used of sufficient
length to seize them without exposing the
captors to much danger. The owners Of
these poisonous reptiles. have descended
thus far with them in Canoe, and propose
going to Philadelphia by the Union Canal
and it will probably be the first boat, as we'll
as the first cargo cfthe kind which will pass
through the canal. They ought to 20 toN
free. The ultimate destination ofthese reo.
tiles is Europe, where they will unquestion-
ably attract much attention, as indeed thew
are objects Of great curiosity in many parts
of our own country Uikes6arre ha.

NAVAL.--The u. S. ships John Adams.
Capt. Wilkinson. and Hornet. Captain Clax-
ton, sailed on the 18th inst. from Matanzas
for Havana. in company with an English
ship. which they had succeeded in getting
off Key Chrystal Padse. with valuable car.
so on board, said to be worth fifty Thousand
dollars at the time the John Adams and
Hornet fell in with her the crew had deser,.
ed her.
